  • Exercises 2 -- Analytical Regression

    • Introduction to Machine Learning

    Due: Monday, September 11, 2023 at 09:00 AM

    Before working through these questions, please study the lecture notes on Regression

    1) Intro to linear regression§

    1.1) §

    Squared error is frequently used as a loss function for regression. Which of the following pictures illustrates the squared loss function? Assume that the dark blue line is described by θ,θ0, the black dots are the (x,y) data, and the light lines indicate the errors we are measuring.

    A
    B
    C

    Select the picture which best illustrates the squared loss function:
    Loading... 100.00%
    You have 1 submission remaining.
    Solution: B

    Explanation:

    Squared loss measures the squared distance between the actual y and the predicted y^=θTx+θ0. Therefore, the picture should depict distances in only y, which corresponds to B.

    1.2) §

    Consider the data set and regression lines in the plot below.

    • The equation of the blue (lower) line is: y=x
    • The equation of the green (upper) line is: y=x+1
    • The data points (in x, y pairs) are: [[[1],3],[[1],1],[[3],2],[[3],6]]

    What is the squared error of each of the points with respect to the blue line?

    Provide a Python list of four numbers (in the order of the points given above).
    Loading... 100.00%
    You have infinitely many submissions remaining.

    Solution: [4, 0, 1, 9]

    Explanation:

    Given the data points and regression line y=x, we calculate the squared error of each point:
    At x=1, the regression predicts y^=1, so the first two errors are (3−1)2=4 and (1−1)2=0.
    At x=3, the regression predicts y^=3, so the last two errors are (2−3)2=1 and (6−3)2=9.

    1.3) §

    Basic linear regression seeks to minimize the mean squared error over all training points:

    J(θ,θ0)=1n∑i=1n(θTx(i)+θ0−y(i))2.
    That means that the gradient (with respect to θ and θ0) of the mean squared error regression criterion has the form of a sum over contributions from individual points. So,
    ∂J∂θ=1n∑i=1n2x(i)(θTx(i)+θ0−y(i))
    and
    ∂J∂θ0=1n∑i=1n2(θTx(i)+θ0−y(i))

    In the following questions, ignore the factor of 1/n and consider just the terms inside the sum.

    What is the contribution from each point to the gradient of the objective with respect to the parameters θ and θ0 of the blue (lower) line?

    (Hint: re-express the above equation in terms of y^=θTx+θ0, the predicted value.)

    Provide a list of four pairs of numbers (as tuples of (∂J∂θ,∂J∂θ0), in the order of the points given above).
    Loading... 100.00%
    You have infinitely many submissions remaining.

    Solution: [(-4, -4), (0, 0), (6, 2), (-18, -6)]

    Explanation:

    We should note that θTx+θ0 is the predicted y^ for the point x. Thus, we can simplify the gradient formula to (−2(y−y^)x,−2(y−y^)). Also note that conceptually y−y^ is the error described by θ,θ0 on the point (x,y). For the blue line, y^=x.
    At (1,3), y^=1, so the gradient is (−2⋅2⋅1,−2⋅2)=(−4,−4).
    At (1,1), y^=1, so the gradient is (−2⋅0⋅1,−2⋅0)=(0,0).
    At (3,2), y^=3, so the gradient is (−2⋅−1⋅3,−2⋅−1)=(6,2).
    At (3,6), y^=3, so the gradient is (−2⋅3⋅3,−2⋅3)=(−18,−6).

    1.4) §

    What is the squared error of each of the points with respect to the green line?

    Provide a list of four numbers (in the order of the points given above).
    Loading... 100.00%
    You have infinitely many submissions remaining.

    Solution: [1, 1, 4, 4]

    Explanation:

    Given data points ((1,3),(1,1),(3,2),(3,6)) and green regression y=x+1, we calculate the squared error of each point.
    At x=1, the regression predicts y^=2, so the first two errors are (3−2)2=1 and (1−2)2=1.
    At x=3, the regression predicts y^=4, so the last two errors are (2−4)2=4 and (4−3)2=4.

    1.5) §

    What is the contribution from each point to the gradient of the objective with respect to the parameters of the green line?
    Provide a list of four pairs of numbers (as tuples, in the order of the points given above).
    Loading... 100.00%
    You have infinitely many submissions remaining.

    Solution: [(-2, -2), (2, 2), (12, 4), (-12, -4)]

    Explanation:

    We should note that θTx+θ0 is the predicted y^ for the point x. Thus, we can simplify the gradient formula to (−2(y−y^)x,−2(y−y^)). Also note that conceptually y−y^ is the error described by θ,θ0 on the point (x,y). For the green line, y^=x+1.
    At (1,3), y^=2, so the gradient is (−2⋅1⋅1,−2⋅1)=(−2,−2).
    At (1,1), y^=2, so the gradient is (−2⋅−1⋅1,−2⋅−1)=(2,2).
    At (3,2), y^=4, so the gradient is (−2⋅−2⋅3,−2⋅−2)=(12,4).
    At (3,6), y^=4, so the gradient is (−2⋅2⋅3,−2⋅2)=(−12,−4).

    1.6) §

    Mark all of the following that are true:

    Loading... 100.00%
    You have infinitely many submissions remaining.

    Solution:

    • The blue line minimizes mean squared error.
    • The green line minimizes mean squared error.
    • The mean squared error from all the points to the blue line is 0.
    • The mean squared error from all the points to the green line is 0.
    • The sum of the gradient contributions in all dimensions from all the points for the blue line is 0.
    • The sum of the gradient contributions in all dimensions from all the points for the green line is 0.
    • Neither line minimizes mean squared error.
    • It is impossible to minimize mean squared error.
    • Both lines minimize mean squared error.

    Explanation:

    The blue line’s mean squared error (MSE) is 14, while the green line’s MSE is 10, so (1) is false and (2) is true. Neither (3) nor (4) are true.
    The blue line’s sum of gradient contributions is (−16,−8), and the green line’s is (0,0), so (5) is false and (6) is true.
    The green line has a zero gradient, so it minimizes the mean squared error. It follows that (7), (8), and (9) are false.

    2) Ridge regression§

    Consider a one-dimensional ordinary least squares regression problem, i.e., x(i)∈R. If we use the squared-norm regularizer on all parameters (i.e. both θ and θ0), we get the canonical ridge regression objective:

    Jridge(θ,θ0)=1n∑i=1nLs(x(i),y(i);θ,θ0)+λ(θ2+θ02)
    where Ls is the usual squared loss.

    In practice, we do not have to strictly follow the canonical form of regularizing λ(θ2+θ02). Instead, we may add regularization penalty on either just θ, or on both θ and θ0. We will consider the effect of these various choices of regularization.

    The figures below plot linear regression results on the basis of only three data points (x(1),y(1)),(x(2),y(2)),(x(3),y(3)). We used various types of regularization to obtain the plots (see below) but got confused about which plot corresponds to which regularization method. Please assign each plot to one (and only one) of the following regularization methods.

    A
    B
    C
    D

    2.1) §

    13∑i=13(y(i)−θx(i)−θ0)2+λθ2 where λ=1 is plot:
    Loading... 100.00%
    You have 0 submissions remaining.
    Solution: B

    Explanation:

    The regularization term λθ2 only penalizes the weights but not the offset θ0, so the slope of the line becomes closer to 0. When λ is small, the regression is nudged to be slightly more horizontal, but the y-intercept does not move downwards (B).

    2.2) §

    13∑i=13(y(i)−θx(i)−θ0)2+λθ2 where λ=10 is plot:
    Loading... 100.00%
    You have 1 submission remaining.
    Solution: D

    Explanation:

    The regularization term λθ2 only penalizes the weights but not the offset θ0, so the slope of the line is more strongly nudged to become closer to 0. When λ is large, the regression approaches horizontal, but the y-intercept does not approach 0 (D).

    2.3) §

    13∑i=13(y(i)−θx(i)−θ0)2+λ(θ2+θ02) where λ=1 is plot:
    Loading... 100.00%
    You have 1 submission remaining.
    Solution: C

    Explanation:

    The regularization term λ(θ2+θ02) penalizes both weights and bias. When λ is small, the line slightly approaches the x axis, so the y-intercept dips slightly (C).

    2.4) §

    13∑i=13(y(i)−θx(i)−θ0)2+λ(θ2+θ02) where λ=10 is plot:
    Loading... 100.00%
    You have 2 submissions remaining.
    Solution: A

    Explanation:

    The regularization term λ(θ2+θ02) penalizes both weights and bias. When λ is large, the entire line approaches the x axis, which has 0 slope and 0 y-intercept (A).
